note.body: Thanks for tracking this down!

target_title: Only Serbian shows up with an unset/C locale

note.body:
Looks like that actual issue was the status check of the ICU APIs.

The `C` locale was actually properly translated but the returned status indicated that a fallback was used, which should not be a reason to reject the translation.

A merge request is available.

target_title: enchant: fix ICU success check
Only Serbian shows up with an unset/C locale

note.body:
I also observed this issue some time ago.

When using `LC_ALL=C.UTF-8`, then:
* [g_get_language_names()](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libspelling/-/blob/0.4.4/lib/enchant/spelling-enchant-provider.c?ref_type=tags#L82) returns typically `{"C.UTF-8", "C", "C"}`
* subsequent [uloc_getDisplayName()](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libspelling/-/blob/0.4.4/lib/enchant/spelling-enchant-provider.c?ref_type=tags#L88) will always return an error because it doesn't understand `C` as a valid locale.
* so [get_display_name()](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libspelling/-/blob/0.4.4/lib/enchant/spelling-enchant-provider.c?ref_type=tags#L80) will return NULL and the menu won't be populated.


We could append some fallback locale like `en_US.UTF-8` to the result of `g_get_language_names` to ensure we display something. Or just let as-is, as it's basically an ICU problem and using a `C` locale is not something usually expected.


That said, it's strange that this "Serbian" appears... Could it be that Serbian is the only lang to have a `C` translation on ICU side?

target_title: Segfault when destroying the buffer early

note.body:
Since this is mitigated on our side, I'm going to close this.

But I definitely suggest spending some time specializing how you do buffer setup and destruction in your applications. This is something we do in Builder/Text Editor as well for example.

target_title: Segfault when destroying the buffer early
Only Serbian shows up with an unset/C locale

note.body:
Cool, I think we can close this then.

Having properly setup i18n has to be done by the application (generally in `main()` or equivalent) and is therefore outside the reach of `libspelling`.

Segfault when destroying the buffer early

note.body: Yeah well this just provides us some guardrails, but it sounds like something should still be done differently app-wise.

target_title: Segfault when destroying the buffer early

note.body:
> but I suspect there might be something app-side that needs to be addressed too

Very likely. FWIW, the sourceview is used *fully*: there are 3 completion providers, highlights are enabled, custom lang specs. Not sure if they have any impact on this issue. Also, it's much easier to reproduce when the buffer text has to be set right after setting up the sourceview.

> Can you try with libspelling pinned to d1b536fadbb5492e8cd61615ab3b84526ef12a14 and see if that resolves things for you?

Now I'm only getting:

`** (dev.geopjr.Tuba:2): WARNING **: 00:44:43.759: (../lib/spelling-text-buffer-adapter.c:168):spelling_text_buffer_adapter_copy_text: code should not be reached`

Thanks!

target_title: Segfault when destroying the buffer early

note.body:
Can you try with libspelling pinned to d1b536fadbb5492e8cd61615ab3b84526ef12a14 and see if that resolves things for you?

We're dealing with tertiary object disposal propagation of weak pointers here, the thing GtkTextBuffer is notoriously bad at. Usually in apps I work around this by design, but hopefully the `GWeakRef` will get us notified earlier than `g_object_add_weak_pointer()` notification can.

push_data.commit_title: engine: use GWeakRef for instance tracking

target_title: Segfault when destroying the buffer early

note.body:
Hrmm, `self->instance` should be cleared when the `buffer` is disposed (not the view) but that is all we need.

We can try to guard it a bit more with a `GWeakRef` but I suspect there might be something app-side that needs to be addressed too.

assertion failed: (word_len > 0) in spelling_enchant_dictionary_contains_word()

note.body: Okay, provenance on the `'debug'` issue seems to be GNOME/libdex@14b0ce00 which makes sense because I copy that around frequently.

target_title: assertion failed: (word_len > 0) in spelling_enchant_dictionary_contains_word()

note.body:
Looks like at some point a c&p error got propagated, so I have a bunch of 

```
if not get_option('debug')
  add_global_arguments('-DG_DISABLE_CAST_CHECKS', language: 'c')
  release_args += [ '-DG_DISABLE_ASSERT' ]
  test_link_args += [
    '-Wl,-Bsymbolic',
    '-fno-plt',
  ]
endif
```

To fix to 

```
if not get_option('buildtype').startswith('debug')
```

target_title: assertion failed: (word_len > 0) in spelling_enchant_dictionary_contains_word()

note.body:
The Fedora spec does:

```	
%build
%meson -Ddocs=false
%meson_build
```

So it's all defaults except for disabled documentation for some reason.

GLib assertions are enabled by default; unless you go out of your way to disable them in your meson.build, they're going to be enabled. So almost the entire distro will have them enabled, with [some](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/glib2/c/d6a5c7751dffaa9f593c6ff54b313f72e37f9c3c?branch=rawhide) [exceptions](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/gtk4/c/b161739e5497014b49c31cff1b07e70461c14aee).

target_title: assertion failed: (word_len > 0) in spelling_enchant_dictionary_contains_word()

note.body: Fixed by making the assertion match the API contract. But one does wonder _why_ Fedora is compiling without the assertions disabled?

target_title: assertion failed: (word_len > 0) in spelling_enchant_dictionary_contains_word()
